Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Plate and Intramedullary Nail Fixation for Displaced Midshaft Clavicle Fractures

Background: This study aimed to compare the long-term outcomes of plate versus intramedullary nail fixation for displaced midshaft clavicle fractures, focusing on disability, implant-related irritation, and removal rates.

Methods: In this randomised controlled trial, 120 patients with displaced midshaft clavicle fractures were enrolled between January 2011 and August 2012. Participants were randomised to receive either plate fixation (n=58) or intramedullary nail fixation (n=62). The primary outcome was disability, measured by the QuickDASH score at a minimum followup of 30 months (mean, 39 months). Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed. Blinding was not specified.

Results: QuickDASH scores showed no significant difference between the plate (1.8 ± 3.6) and intramedullary nail groups (1.8 ± 7.2; mean difference, −0.7; 95% CI, −2.2 to 2.04; p=0.95). Implant-related irritation was similar between groups (70% vs. 66%; relative risk, 1.05; 95% CI, 0.82–1.35; p=0.683). Intramedullary fixation had a higher implant removal rate (82% vs. 50%; relative risk, 1.65; 95% CI, 1.24–2.19; p<0.001). No major complications occurred after the 1-year followup.

Interpretation: Both fixation methods resulted in excellent disability scores. Implant-related irritation was common, leading to high removal rates. Future research should explore risk factors for implant irritation or removal.

Trial registration: Not provided. Funding: Not reported.
